The Context: Muscle Atrophy in Space

Who is at Risk?

Every astronaut on a long-duration mission faces this challenge. Whether it's a 6-month stay on the ISS or a 3-year journey to Mars, the human body adapts to its environmentâ€”often in ways we don't want.

Astronauts face a unique challenge: microgravity. On Earth, our muscles are constantly working against gravity to support our weight and move us around. In space, this load disappears.

Without gravity pulling on them, muscles begin to weaken immediately. This isn't just about strength; it's about safety. A weakened crew member might struggle with emergency procedures or be unable to walk upon returning to Earth (or landing on Mars).

Why Does It Happen?

Use it or lose it. On Earth, just standing up requires your "anti-gravity" muscles (legs and spine) to work against 1G of force. In space, that load disappears.

The body, being efficient, stops maintaining muscle it doesn't need. The result? Up to 30% muscle mass loss in just six months. Bones also become brittle, increasing fracture risk.
